climbs.name: Pull my Thumb
climbs.fa: Eric Cornish TR, Robert Dalton, Steve Delisle FA 30 April 2021

content.description:
Start where the two vertical cracks meet the horizontal crack then work your way up the vertical cracks placing gear small gear where you can, follow the cracks up to the small ledge where you can walk up the little ramp. From the large ledge place gear at your leisure in the double cracks to the top of the wall.



Pull my Thumb is on the left wall of Howe Crag and two meters to the left of the start of Tyno.

Standard Rack ,Ring anchors at the top.

Step up on the small bulges to grab the small right leaning sidepull to work your way up to the blank face. The start of the route has two bolts that are close together to protect against ground fall.

Now the fun starts. Place as much protection as you want as the horizontal cracks will eat gear. After busting out your finest moves to the first ledge, relax and enjoy the great climbing up to the second ledge via another right leaning crack. Then climb the corner crack to the anchors at the top of the wall.



It is on the far Right of the Left wall two meters to the left of Running on Empty


two lower bolts ,standard rack andÂ  ring anchors at the top.

Howe Crag has two walls with mainly traditional routes. Of the dozen+ climbs, most of them have tree or gear anchors with only a few that have ring anchors. To access the top there is a path to the righthand side of the cliff. This crag seems to have a little more wind then its neighbor, Columbus wall, so there are fewer bugs.

Like most of the Halifax area you can expect sticky (sharp) granite at this crag.
